title: I have to write a script outline for my intro to film class. The film only has to be 1-2 min and has to be one shot. Is anyone able to help me with ideas and format? - Quora

response.answer_text: Legend has it that Ernest Hemingway won a bet by writing the six-word “short” story “For sale: baby shoes. Never worn.” making it an extreme example of what is called flash fiction or sudden fiction. Although it is often attributed to Ernest Hemingway, the link to him is unsubstantiated and similar stories predate him. If you can adapt that to a single shot, you’ve got a solid start. Of course, offer the attribution as “the final image allegedly written by Ernest Hemingway”. You might start with a shot of a funeral in progress that, in some visual way, indicates a woman was beaten to death by someone. Then, the camera pans 180 degrees to a small table in the back of the church, where you see two brand new baby shoes, and the hand-written sign. So, not to belabor the point, you’ve structured it with Act 1 and Act 2 in the initial part of the shot, and then you pay it off in Act 3 after the pan. Or (Act 2) you show a sign against violence against women at some point either before or after the pan. As for the format, outlines and treatments are written in present tense, rather than past tense as fiction is normally written. Just tell your shot as efficiently as possible. You could include the description, “An adaptation of…” and the source attribution to avoid any charges of so-called plagiarism, but make sure that doesn’t technically add a second shot. If you haven’t picked it up, act structure is all about meaning. You set up the death of the woman (act 1), you advance her death (act 2), and you pay off or resolve her death (act 3). So, while the plot (what happens) is all about how it plays out, the meaning structure is all about what it means. Your film MUST mean something! I go into this in great detail in both books below. If it needs to be a completely original idea, try brainstorming along a similar path. Good luck. For more information on writing, I can recommend LATERAL SCREENWRITING, my own book, because it is not a "My way or the highway" type of book, and it has LOTS of Hollywood stories that can fill in the gaps in your understanding. After it is over, you should have a good place to start from. Also, I just published THE LAST REVEAL - Movies, Screenwriting, and the Decline of Western Cinemazation.

Yes, your instructor can help. That’s their role in this whole process. As for the format, I am shocked that an example has not already been offered to the students in the class. After all, if the instructor expects a certain format, why wouldn’t they tell you what that format is?
